abstract.text: Verify your sampler state configurations by examining their properties.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The Metal debugger allows you to inspect a sampler state with the Sampler State viewer.
After opening a sampler state, you can view its associated properties and preview the sampling behavior.
The Sampler State viewer shows the properties of your sampler state on the left (as configured by
) and a preview on the right. The preview illustrates how pixels in a texture appear when using your sampler state.
The square region in the center of the preview corresponds to UV coordinates within the range of
You can use the preview to quickly verify the configuration for your sampler state.
For example, if you want a texture to mirror, but it’s drawing a constant value instead, you can check the sampler state.
In the screenshot below, the sampler state is configured to clamp to a border color that’s opaque black, rather than using mirror repeat as the address mode:
The properties you configure when creating a sampler state determine how a texture looks when sampling it.
The properties related to filtering control how pixels combine when the sample footprint is either larger or smaller than a pixel, or when it’s between mipmap levels.
The address mode determines the texture coordinate at each pixel when a read falls outside the bounds of a texture. You can try using different combinations of filtering
and addressing modes until you achieve your desired look.

Xcode-PageImage-card.png.alt: The Xcode logo on a blue gradient background.

abstract.text: Build, test, and submit your app with Apple’s integrated development environment.
Manage your Metal app’s memory usage by inspecting its resources.
Reveal ray intersection bottlenecks by examining your acceleration structures.
Confirm your buffer formats by examining buffer content.
Determine how your render and compute passes behave by examining their properties.
Improve your app’s shader performance by examining and editing your shaders.
Discover issues in your textures by examining their content.
Discover issues by examining the bound resources at any point in an encoder.

doc://com.apple.Xcode/documentation/Xcod.title: Inspecting the bound resources for a command

abstract.text: Debug and profile your Metal workload with a GPU trace.
Identify and address issues in your app using the Xcode debugger, Xcode Organizer, Metal debugger, and Instruments.
Out-of-range texture coordinates return the value specified by the [`borderColor`](doc://com.apple.metal/documentation/Metal/MTLSamplerDescriptor/borderColor) property.
Texture coordinates are clamped between `0.0` and `1.0`, inclusive.
Out-of-range texture coordinates return transparent zero `(0,0,0,0)` for images with an alpha channel and return opaque zero `(0,0,0,1)` for images without an alpha channel.
Between `-1.0` and `1.0`, the texture coordinates are mirrored across the axis; outside `-1.0` and `1.0`, texture coordinates are clamped.
Between `-1.0` and `1.0`, the texture coordinates are mirrored across the axis; outside `-1.0` and `1.0`, the image is repeated.
Texture coordinates wrap to the other side of the texture, effectively keeping only the fractional part of the texture coordinate.
An opaque black color `(0,0,0,1)` for texture values outside the border
An opaque white color `(1,1,1,1)` for texture values outside the border.
A transparent black color `(0,0,0,0)` for texture values outside the border.
An object that you use to configure a texture sampler.
Select two pixels in each dimension and interpolate linearly between them.
Select the single pixel nearest to the sample point.
